instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01700: What is 820-01700? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3217: What is CD3217? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v short on <SIGNAL>PP1V5_UPC_TB_LDO_CORE</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Board had a little bit of corrosion around UB400 and CB404/<SIGNAL>PP1V5_UPC_TB_LDO_CORE</SIGNAL> was shorted.

After removing short and replacing CB404 as well as UB400 and reballing UB300 the problem is the same.

What's weird is that <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TB_LDO</SIGNAL> starts with a higher voltage when the charger is first connected 5V~ then it starts to drop slowly.

The only port that reboots is UB400 all others stay at 5V without rebooting.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v short on <SIGNAL>PP1V5_UPC_TB_LDO_CORE</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
5V is not good for 3V3 LDO at any moment; this point to bad UB400.
Try interchanging UB300/400.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v short on <SIGNAL>PP1V5_UPC_TB_LDO_CORE</SIGNAL>
threads.message: When I swap them UB400 now has 0V on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TB_LDO</SIGNAL> and weirdly UB400 is still the only only one that reboots even after swapping CD3217s

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v short on <SIGNAL>PP1V5_UPC_TB_LDO_CORE</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Something more is affected by corrosion in that area.
Check all resistors and caps.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v short on <SIGNAL>PP1V5_UPC_TB_LDO_CORE</SIGNAL>
threads.message: CB408 was slightly corroded fixed that and also replaced the other <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> on that same side, now both of them restart, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TB_LDO</SIGNAL> is now 3.3V steady, the other 2 ports on the other side don't restart, should I replace those 2 as well?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v short on <SIGNAL>PP1V5_UPC_TB_LDO_CORE</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I expect to have the problem located on the corroded area.
Change the other <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> chips, just in case.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v short on <SIGNAL>PP1V5_UPC_TB_LDO_CORE</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Ok I am back with this board again, now I have replaced all 4 <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> and now all of them get 5V and about 0.270a on all 4 ports on both sides so that will be on all 8 port options, the battery had some charge left on it so the Mac now turns on and battery is recognized.

With battery connected I get 20v most of the time but 0.018a and Mac wont charge, also tested with new battery and same thing, sometimes with battery connected I still only get 5v on charger meter.

All test done with 96w charger.

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC_X</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> 1.5V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> 1.8V 

PPBUS 12.3V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v short on <SIGNAL>PP1V5_UPC_TB_LDO_CORE</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
You still have problems on USB-C areas.
Battery can't be charged until get the correct <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> with charger alone.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v short on <SIGNAL>PP1V5_UPC_TB_LDO_CORE</SIGNAL>
threads.message: That part is now clear to me, I have checked all caps and resistors around the affected area against another same board, and all <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> are new, also checked the entire board and found nothing else, but still only 5 volts, any pointers you can give for me to check?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v short on <SIGNAL>PP1V5_UPC_TB_LDO_CORE</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
New is not equal with "good", when you buy chips form China.

Just in case, try DFU...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v short on <SIGNAL>PP1V5_UPC_TB_LDO_CORE</SIGNAL>
threads.message: The <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> came from a board that had 20v on all ports but had an internal short between board layers so I know there are good, revive DFU was done and succeed but problem is still there, should I try restore after backing data?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v short on <SIGNAL>PP1V5_UPC_TB_LDO_CORE</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Probably not the solution, but try it.
Backup data anyway!
